channel.title: Hammering out body dents
channel.description:
Hello.
Today I accidently pressed the remote start on my car. For some reason, it was in gear, it started, and collided with a object.
Now, there is some body damage on the left side of the engine compartment.
Can I hammer these out myself?

item.title: Hammering out body dents
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

SonGoku:

It’s a standard transmission. There’s no park

Well there you go, all of those remote starters specifically say they should NOT be installed on a manual transmission for just this reason. You should either remove it (I guess I wouldn’t), find a way to disable it if the car isn’t in neutral, or just make damn sure that the car is in neutral with the parking brake on every time you stop it.

Read full topic

item.title: Hammering out body dents
item.dc:creator: @SonGoku SonGoku
item.description:
@SonGoku wrote:

It’s a standard transmission. There’s no park

Read full topic

item.title: Hammering out body dents
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

wtf, all the cars ive ever driven dont let me turn off the motor unless its in park

Read full topic

item.title: Hammering out body dents
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Also, why wasn’t it in park? You should leave it in park all the time.

Price a new fender, you can have it painted and put it on yourself pretty cheaply.

Read full topic

item.title: Hammering out body dents
item.dc:creator: @SonGoku SonGoku
item.description:
@SonGoku wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:2, topic:300108”]That sucks, and honestly it should not have happened ever. If you had the remote starter installed by someone, or if it came that way from the factory you should have them repair the damage. I have installed a few remote starters myself in various cars, but every single one has a kill switch so it won’t let the car start if it is not in park. If it isn’t your fault and you can get someone else to repair it I wouldn’t touch it.

As to the body repair, you can hammer them out yourself, but unless you are a very experienced body work guy it will never even look remotely right. Chances are even if you took it to a body shop they would just replace the fender (or whatever body panel it is) which you can do yourself without many problems, and fairly cheaply.[/quote]

The guy who I bought it from installed it himself I think. He may of left out a saftey or something. I’ve disabled it until winter so this accident can’t happen again.

I wan’t to avoid going to the body shop, it would probably cost more money then the value of the car.

Read full topic

item.title: Hammering out body dents
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

That sucks, and honestly it should not have happened ever. If you had the remote starter installed by someone, or if it came that way from the factory you should have them repair the damage. I have installed a few remote starters myself in various cars, but every single one has a kill switch so it won’t let the car start if it is not in park. If it isn’t your fault and you can get someone else to repair it I wouldn’t touch it.

As to the body repair, you can hammer them out yourself, but unless you are a very experienced body work guy it will never even look remotely right. Chances are even if you took it to a body shop they would just replace the fender (or whatever body panel it is) which you can do yourself without many problems, and fairly cheaply.

Read full topic
